title: What is the difference between life and free life according to "Nir"?
first_phrase: In this text, the author explores the distinction between "life" and "free life," highlighting how even the physical world is dominated by a specific idea or function. The text delves into the nature of psychic life and how it is characterized by blind instincts and habits. The author suggests that spirits exist behind natural laws and that they are driven by a fixed monodism, leading to constant laws like those governing water. The text's last 200 tokens discuss how the fixed nature of monodism dictates constant laws like those governing water, as spirits are driven by a specific function or idea. The author also explores how spontaneity can only be identified by identifying oneself with its intended purpose, which limits the ability to act differently.

last_phrase: In conclusion, the consistent laws governing the physical perception and manifestation of water highlight the fixity of the monoidism that underpins the universe. The only way to alter this fixed reality is by identification with what is desired, or through the resurrection of a mage's power. Such a view can be found in various magical teachings, where fluid condensations are bound by their fixed determination of life and inexorable will to their functions. These teachings also suggest that the magical power to free and immortalize them comes from water, which quenches their thirst and liberates them through infusion with negative and voluntary freedom.
